name: DMT-Assisted Therapy
summary: Investigational psychedelic-assisted therapy using N,N-dimethyltryptamine (DMT), a short-acting tryptamine hallucinogen. Studies explore its potential for depression, anxiety, addiction, and end-of-life distress.
description: DMT is a potent, fast-acting serotonergic psychedelic naturally occurring in plants and endogenous human metabolism. In therapeutic contexts, DMT is administered via intravenous or intramuscular routes, producing an intense but brief psychedelic state (5–30 minutes). Early-phase clinical studies and preclinical work suggest rapid effects on mood and neural plasticity, potentially offering a novel treatment for mental health disorders. Investigational protocols pair DMT with psychotherapy, preparation, and integration. Its extremely short duration differentiates it from psilocybin or LSD, raising interest in its potential as a more clinic-manageable psychedelic intervention.

metadata.session_duration: 5–30 minutes (psychedelic experience), with 1–2 hours preparation and integration
metadata.treatment_duration: Single or multiple sessions within structured therapy

contraindications: Personal or family history of psychosis
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally well tolerated in controlled settings; rapid onset and offset reduce risks of prolonged dysregulation. Risks include transient anxiety, tachycardia, hypertension, dissociation, and potential psychological distress.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Early-phase clinical trials and preclinical evidence
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple ongoing studies exploring DMT in depression and addiction treatment.

sections.text: DMT is a serotonergic psychedelic primarily acting as a 5-HT2A receptor agonist, with additional activity at 5-HT1A and sigma-1 receptors. Its rapid onset triggers profound alterations in consciousness, perception, and emotional processing. Preclinical evidence suggests DMT enhances neuroplasticity, synaptogenesis, and stress resilience. In therapy, the psychedelic state may facilitate breakthroughs in cognition, emotional regulation, and therapeutic alliance.

sections.preparation: Psychological screening, medical evaluation, therapeutic preparation.
procedure: Administration of IV or IM DMT in a clinical/therapeutic environment
Acute monitoring during the 5–30 minute psychedelic state
Integration therapy session(s) following the psychedelic exposure
sections.frequency: Single or repeated sessions, depending on trial design
sections.duration: Core psychedelic effects last minutes; total therapeutic session ~1–2 hours
sections.total_treatment_time: Varies; often several sessions including prep and integration

long_term: Sustained antidepressant effects in some patients

rare: Triggering psychotic episode in vulnerable individuals

absolute: History of schizophrenia or psychotic disorders
relative: Use of serotonergic medications (risk of serotonin syndrome)

ideal_candidates: Patients in palliative care with end-of-life anxiety
Individuals with substance use disorders in structured programs

studies: Phase I/II trials of IV DMT in depression showing safety and preliminary efficacy.
Preclinical studies showing rapid-acting antidepressant-like effects of DMT.
Comparisons with ayahuasca studies demonstrating potential for mood and addiction improvements.
sections.limitations: Limited sample sizes; short follow-up durations; optimal protocols (dose, frequency) not yet established.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Projected to be moderate-to-high due to clinical monitoring
